title-group.article-title: Brachial Artery Aneurysm With “Blue Finger Syndrome” After Ligation of a Remote Brachial Artery-Cephalic Vein Fistula

article-meta.aff: 1Lehigh Valley Health Network, Allentown, PA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Ramon Garza III, Lehigh Valley Health Network, Cedar Crest & I-78, Allentown, PA 18105, USA. Email: RamonGarza3@gmail.com

abstract.p: Upper extremity aneurysms are relatively infrequent when compared to other vessels in the body. However, a combination of factors occurring following arteriovenous fistula (AVF) ligation can lead to dilation of the brachial artery. Periodic follow-up after AVF creation can help prevent complications. We report a case of an immunosuppressed, patient with renal transplant who presented with delayed onset digital ischemia following ligation of a remotely created brachial artery-cephalic vein fistula.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As early as the 18th century, aneurysmal changes in the inflow vessels have been described following arteriovenous fistula (AVF) ligation. 1,2 Following the development of an AVF, whether surgical or traumatic in origin, high blood flow can trigger the release of a nitric oxide from the endothelial cells. This can potentially lead to dilatation of the vessel with high flow. 3,4 Long-standing high flow may result in transverse tears in the internal elastic membrane, which may lead to further dilation of the artery proximal to the fistula site. 5,6 Additionally, studies suggest that immunosuppression with corticosteroids may promote the development of arterial aneurysms. 4,7 The combination of these factors presents a unique situation in patients with renal transplant who had been previously dialyzed with an AVF. We describe an immunosuppressed patient with renal transplant with pandilatation of his brachial artery who presented with delayed onset digital ischemia following ligation of a remotely created brachial artery–cephalic vein fistula.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 47-year-old male was admitted to our hospital with a chief complaint of pain and discoloration of the distal fingertips of his right hand. His past medical history was significant for polycystic kidney disease resulting in renal failure. He underwent creation of a right brachial-cephalic AVF at an outside institution and received hemodialysis for 15 months until receiving a nonliving donor kidney transplant. He was maintained on immunosuppressive therapy consisting of tacrolimus and prednisone. Seven years after his transplant, the patient noticed increased pain and swelling in proximity to his fistula. He was seen and evaluated by a surgeon at an outside hospital who ligated the AVF with resection of the dilated outflow cephalic vein. The patient remained asymptomatic postoperatively until 1 year after his AVF ligation when he developed discoloration and paresthesias of several fingertips in his right hand and intermittent discomfort in his right forearm. His sensation and motor function appeared normal. Physical examination showed cyanotic discoloration of the right thumb, ring, and little finger despite easily palpable brachial, radial, and ulnar pulses (Figure 1). The patient was sensory-motor intact. He was admitted with the diagnosis of atheroembolism and placed on an intravenous heparin infusion. An arterial duplex was obtained and showed the brachial artery measuring 23 mm in maximal diameter with prominent mural thrombus. A transfemoral arteriogram of the right upper extremity demonstrated aneurysmal changes in the brachial artery from its origin to the elbow, with normal appearing forearm, palmar, and digital vessels (Figures 2 –4). He underwent resection of the brachial artery with reconstruction using an interposition reversed greater saphenous vein graft (Figures 5 and 6). Histologic examination of the brachial artery revealed an aneurysm with myxomatous degeneration and partial chronic thrombus (Figure 7). The patient recovered uneventfully with complete resolution of his symptoms.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Aneurysm formation is defined as a blood vessel dilation >50% of the normal expected diameter with dilatation including all the 3 layers of the arterial wall. 7 Upper extremity aneurysms are relatively infrequent when compared to other vessels in the body. In men, an aneurysm of the brachial artery will measure at a minimum of 6.15 mm; for women a minimum of 5.25 mm. 1,4,8 Symptoms are typically ischemic in nature, resulting from decreased flow and/or distal emboli as our patient demonstrated. It is thought that thrombus can form in the wall of the aneurysmal artery because of turbulent flow and mural changes within the artery. The risk of rupture is low. 7 Previous reports in the literature recommend routine arterial duplex studies for patients who have undergone ligation of long-standing traumatic or iatrogenic AVF to prevent these types of complications. 8 We recommend periodic follow-up for any patient who has undergone creation of an AVF, with particular attention to those patients who are subsequently immunosuppressed after receiving a renal or other organ transplant. Additionally, we feel that routine imaging is not a cost-effective means of following these patients as history and physical examination are sufficient. Imaging should be reserved for patients who are symptomatic or have physical examination findings consistent with an arterial aneurysm.
